Title.En: Designing Flexible and Stretchable Electronics for Real-World Applications

Description.En:
**Our Problem to be solved:**  

Develop a conceptual design for a flexible and stretchable electronic device or sensor tailored to a specific application, such as wearable healthcare monitoring or robotic touch sensors.  

For this, it is necessary to:

- understand the material properties required for the device (e.g., flexibility, conductivity);
- address challenges in device design, such as stability, scalability, and environmental impact; and
- demonstrate societal, industrial, or scientific relevance for the proposed device.

**Expected Impact**  

Participants will gain foundational knowledge of soft electronics and hands-on experience with theoretical device design. By focusing on practical applications, this module equips students with skills to address real-world technological challenges, fostering innovation in industries like healthcare and robotics.

Title.En: Understand the material properties required for the device

NoteLiteral.En: By the end of the course learners are able to explain and make informe decission about material properties (e.g., flexibility, conductivity) required for the device and its application.

Title.En: Make decisions in device design, such as stability, scalability, and environmental impact

NoteLiteral.En: By the end of the course learners are able to make decisions in device design, such as stability, scalability, and environmental impact.

Title.En: Demonstrate societal, industrial, or scientific relevance for the proposed device

NoteLiteral.En: By the end of the course learners are able to demonstrate societal, industrial, or scientific relevance for the proposed device.

Title.En: Designing Flexible and Stretchable Electronics for Real-World Applications
Designing Flexible and Stretchable Electronics for Real-World Applications

MoreInformation.NoteLiteral:
**Schedule:**

The micromodule lasts five weeks. Weeks 1-3 consist of 2 hours of lecture and one hour of seminar each. Weeks 4 and 5 consist of two hours of seminar each. In the seminar students work on their designs. In addition to the lecture and seminar, students work 1-2 hours per week to continue working on their designs in small groups. 

LECTURE:

- March 10th 15:00 – 16:30 CEST / 14:00 – 15:30  BST

- March 17th 15:00 – 16:30 CEST / 14:00 – 15:30  BST

- March 24th 15:00 – 16:30 CEST / 14:00 – 15:30  BST

SEMINAR

- March 18th 15:00 – 16:30 CEST / 14:00 – 15:30  BST

- March 25th 15:00 – 16:30 CEST / 14:00 – 15:30  BST

- April 1st 15:00 – 16:30 CEST / 14:00 – 15:30  BST

FINAL PRESENTATION

- April 8th 15:00 – 16:30 CEST / 14:00 – 15:30  BST

**Expectations from Students:**

Collaborate in interdisciplinary teams to develop a theoretical device design and present a final concept, including the application, materials, and theoretical design, in a 15 minute presentation.

No written assignments are required.
Exploring the Fundamentals of Soft Polymer Electronics and Their Practical Impact

The field of soft polymer electronics is at the forefront of technological innovation, enabling new possibilities in wearables, healthcare monitoring, flexible displays, and robotics. These systems rely on unique material properties like elasticity and conductivity, combined with innovative device designs. This module introduces participants to the basics of material science and device engineering for flexible electronics, focusing on stretchable sensors and devices such as organic field-effect transistors (OFETs) and organic electrochemical transistors (OECTs). It provides a condensed and focused exploration of the key aspects of soft electronics, including material properties, device design, and applications.

This mini-module is open to bachelor’s students in their final year or master’s students with an interest in materials science, electronics, or device engineering. No prior knowledge is required.

To apply for the course, please provide a brief self-description (approximately ¼ to ½ page). This should include information about what you are currently studying, your academic background, and whether you have any prior experience in the subject area. If there are specific topics or aspects of the course that interest you, feel free to mention them as well.
